title: Small court claim defendant doesn't want to pay court fees.
self_text: I'm trying to get a refund for a pair of shoes that I consider faulty but the store managers don't. Here is the defendants response  The pair is not faulty, the personnel the customer refers to Brick Lane had just started work and was inexperieced, this is why the pair was sent to a senior and expereinced manager to inspect the item. We have been an authorised stockists for over 30 years and the pair has been inspected by 3 seperate senior managers and we have also consulted with Dr Martens on this and all parties conclude the item is not faulty. The customer was offered an exchange or credit note, which they have not taken up to date, the pair is currently with us. How ever for the sake of simplicity we are willing to refund the purchase price, of the pair and the additonal purchase the customer made a Tower Bag of a total of £159.80, we are nor prepared to pay any addtional costs and the customer needs to withdraw the claim in full once we refund £159.80. If the customer returns to the store the purchase was made in,so the Camden branch with their receipt we and refund the money to their original card they used to make the purchase with. We hope this will settle the matter and satisfy the customer and the court  What is my best course of action:  A - Go to the store and get the 159.80 refund and lose the 35gbp fee  B - Go to the store and get the 159.80 refund and further challenge for the 35gbp fee  C - Challenge the full 159.80 + 35gbp fee through the court system

title: Buying a House in Illinois -- Bad Idea?
self_text: My wife and I found a town we like in the Metro East region (Illinois suburbs of St. Louis). The houses here are somewhat affordable at 250k to 400k for a McMansion 2,500 square feet type house, but I worry about the property taxes and the long term fiscal health of the state. I actually used to live in Cook County and the government was enough of a corrupt mess to cause people like me to leave. My fourth b.s. red light violation ticket in the mail was enough. I’m telling you, I'm not doing this again.  I'm considering if it's worth it to buy a house in the metro east or just to wait it out.

title: Small court claim defendant doesn't want to pay court fees.
self_text: I'm trying to get a refund for a pair of shoes that I consider faulty but the store managers don't. Here is the defendants response  The pair is not faulty, the personnel the customer refers to Brick Lane had just started work and was inexperieced, this is why the pair was sent to a senior and expereinced manager to inspect the item. We have been an authorised stockists for over 30 years and the pair has been inspected by 3 seperate senior managers and we have also consulted with Dr Martens on this and all parties conclude the item is not faulty. The customer was offered an exchange or credit note, which they have not taken up to date, the pair is currently with us. How ever for the sake of simplicity we are willing to refund the purchase price, of the pair and the additonal purchase the customer made a Tower Bag of a total of £159.80, we are nor prepared to pay any addtional costs and the customer needs to withdraw the claim in full once we refund £159.80. If the customer returns to the store the purchase was made in,so the Camden branch with their receipt we and refund the money to their original card they used to make the purchase with. We hope this will settle the matter and satisfy the customer and the court  What is my best course of action:  A - Go to the store and get the 159.80 refund and lose the 35gbp fee  B - Go to the store and get the 159.80 refund and further challenge for the 35gbp fee  C - Challenge the full 159.80 + 35gbp fee through the court system

title: Budget PC Build for 1080p Gaming
self_text:
Hi everyone! I'm putting together my first gaming PC and aiming for a budget build around $800-$1000 USD. I mostly want to play esports titles like Valorant, League of Legends, and CS:GO, as well as some AAA games at 1080p with medium settings. I’m open to suggestions and prioritizing value for money. Here's what I'm currently considering:

*   **CPU:** AMD Ryzen 5 5600 ($130 - $150)
*   **Motherboard:**  ASRock B450M Steel Legend ($80 - $100)
*   **RAM:** 16GB (2x8GB) DDR4 3200MHz CL16 ($50 - $70)
*   **Graphics Card:** AMD Radeon RX 6600 ($200 - $250)
*   **Storage:** 1TB NVMe SSD ($60 - $80)
*   **Power Supply:** Corsair CX550M 550W 80+ Bronze ($60 - $80)
*   **Case:**  NZXT H510 Case ($60 - $80)

Are there any major component swaps you’d recommend to improve performance or value, or any potential bottlenecks I should be aware of? Thanks in advance for your help!

title: PC randomly turns off when booting up games or doing certain things.
self_text: Hi. I was wondering if someone could help me with my computer. For the past 6 months at least, it's been randomly turning off on certain games or while booting up games. I recently bought a new motherboard, processor, cpu cooler, and ssd to try and fix this. These current specs are MSI MPG B550 Gaming Plus, Ryzen 7 5700x, GTX 1660 Super.  I have 16 gb of ram and 650 watts of power. I had to do a manual bios update with the flash button on the motherboard to allow support for the processor. After fixing my computer I loaded up warzone from my harddrive and played a game. Everything went well. My brother then took a turn after me and right when he clicked to go back to the lobby, the computer, monitor, and all of the lights turned off completely. When we turned it back on, the CPU light went on so we turned it back off immediately. We then turned it on again for the CPU light to go on for a few seconds until it turned off, to the VGA light going on and turning off, to the boot light going on and off, until it began booting normally. I reset my computer and my drives and then redownloaded windows onto my SSD. I redownloaded call of duty but every time I open it, my computer turns off. I can’t even click the button to turn it back on anymore. I have to flip the power supply switch like 4 or 5 times before it finally turns on. Any ideas?
subreddit:
pcmasterrace

If the customer returns to the store the purchase was made in,so the Camden branch with their receipt we and refund the money to their original card they used to make the purchase with. We hope this will settle the matter and satisfy the customer and the court  What is my best course of action:  A - Go to the store and get the 159.80 refund and lose the 35gbp fee  B - Go to the store and get the 159.80 refund and further challenge for the 35gbp fee  C - Challenge the full 159.80 + 35gbp fee through the court system

title: ELI5 Reverse Mortgages
self_text: If my understanding of a mortgage is accurate, in that you (for lack of a better word) sell your house to the bank and buy it back, in monthly payments, then a reverse mortgage would be the bank slowly buying your house out from under you.Ive heard it described as a scam to get the old and financially illiterate people out of their homes so the bank can resell the house at a profit. I have to assume I misunderstood some part of this cuz none of that seems like it should be legal.
